title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" allows for direct primary care service arrangements where individuals pay a fixed fee for ongoing primary care services. This arrangement is not considered a health plan or insurance. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows for direct primary care service arrangements with fixed fees for ongoing services. The amendment includes periodic provider fees as medical care and applies to taxable years after the Act's enactment. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows for direct primary care service arrangements with fixed fees for ongoing services, including a model for reimbursing qualified direct primary care medical home practices under Medicare. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows for direct primary care service arrangements with fixed fees for ongoing services, including a model for reimbursing qualified direct primary care medical home practices under Medicare. The Secretary will establish a periodic fee for each individual enrolled in the practice, capped at twenty percent of estimated monthly costs payable from Medicare funds. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows direct primary care practices to receive a periodic fee adjustment based on performance benchmarks in the Medicare shared savings program. If a qualified practice meets or exceeds the benchmark, the fee for each enrolled individual increases by 5 percent in the second year of the model. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows direct primary care practices to receive a periodic fee adjustment based on performance benchmarks in the Medicare shared savings program. If a qualified practice does not meet the benchmark for two consecutive years, the participation in the model will be terminated. Qualified practices must provide preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, and coordinate with specialty and hospital care. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows direct primary care practices to receive a periodic fee adjustment based on performance benchmarks in the Medicare shared savings program. Qualified practices must provide preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, and coordinate with specialty and hospital care. Priority is given to practices enrolling dual eligible individuals. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows direct primary care practices to participate in a model under which care provided in a qualified practice is not considered insurance and is not regulated as such. Practices must report annually on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows direct primary care practices to participate in a model where patient data, including prior claims data, is provided for clinical purposes. Physicians who have opted out of Medicare may also participate in the qualified direct primary care model. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows direct primary care practices to participate in a model where payment can be made for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries with whom the physician has a private contract. Physicians excluded from federal health care programs cannot participate in this model, which will be conducted for a minimum of 3 years. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows qualified direct primary care medical home practices to participate in a model where payment can be made for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries with whom the physician has a private contract. If the practice meets certain requirements, it can continue permanently, and if a majority of practices meet the requirements, the model will be expanded nationwide. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows Medicare Advantage organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices for primary care services, including shared savings agreements. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice is defined as one described in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
